reviews.review: I have to say I was rather disappointed this time I ate there.  The bread was pretty good, but the olive oil had no flavor, was simply oil.  The salad that came with my dinner was lettuce, tomatoes, etc., also little flavor, the simple oil and vinegar dressing had too much vinegar, I didn't finish it.  I had chicken stuffed with spinach in coconut oil, which sounded great, but was also very bland.  the person with whom I was dining had chicken kabob, which was pretty good with the sauce.  But her drink had almost no alcohol in it.  Although I have been here before, I wouldn't go back.

reviews.name: Daniel B.
reviews.review: First time to eat Turkish cuisine and I will definitely be back. The waiter was very friendly and it was a great environment. I shared the hummus as an appetizer and ended up ordering the Iskender Kabob. Both were much to my liking and I would recommend them for any first-timer with Turkish dishes.

reviews.name: Katie K.
reviews.review: We come here often in the winter because we like to get the chicken stew (It's a great cold weather dish.).  The name does not do it justice though, as I would never order anything called chicken stew at a restaurant, but it's amazing.  We always start off with the ezme, which is always really nice and flavorful, and just a bit spicy.  We also order the hot apple tea, which is wonderful.  As I found out during our last visit, they sell it in their little gift shop in the back of the restaurant.  We didn't go for about eight months or so, and when we finally went again, they still knew our order, which was really great.  It's the kind of place that just makes you feel good.

reviews.name: Faith B.
reviews.review: This is my favorite Nashville-restaurant overall. Since I moved here more than 10 years ago, the food quality and the service have been consistently good. Vegetarians can easily eat here along with their meat-eater friends, but strict veggies only have  one or two entree options.The Turkish white and red wines make an affordable and authentic option to the other wines on the menu.Their hummus is excellent, but for a real treat, try the Ezme or the Haydari or ask them to give you half and half. They will.

reviews.name: Amber K.
reviews.review: This place was pretty good, it looked closed at first but I guess it just wasn't very busy. The hummus and pita bread were awesome. The apricot juice and hot apple tea were also very good. I had the beef shish kebab and my husband had the lamb, both were good but could have used a little more seasoning in my opinion, as with the rice pilaf. Nice little place and very courteous staff.

reviews.name: Kelly F.
reviews.review: I am a restaurant snob, but this one deserves a 5 star rating. Who would have guessed a little place in a strip mall could do Turkish so well. Try the red Turish wine - reasonable and good. Good sampler platter and kabobs.

reviews.name: Micheal P.
reviews.review: Anatolia isn't the best turkish food that I've ever had, but it is certainly the best in Nashville and surrounding areas. They do a few things really well and their service is friendly.Not everything on the menu stacks up, so here's what I would recommend.Appetizers - Haydari - a yogurt based dip - DELICIOUS, especially with the warm bread they bring you! Also, ezme - a red pepper/tomato (?) dip.DinnerThe manti - turkish ravioli filled with meat in a yogurt-based white garlic sauce. The only thing I ever order now. Little tiny pillows of awesome. lahmacun - turkish pizza - This is only available on certain days because it needs to be cooked in a certain oven... My husband really enjoys it.DessertKunefe- cheese with crispy filo dough on top. Oh! How we love it! Order it early because it takes them a long time to make it. Have it with a cup of turkish coffee. Nearly finish your cup of coffee and then flip it over in the saucer and ask Dennis to read your fortune!

reviews.name: Charles F.
reviews.review: Road-tripping, I have Yelp to thank for landing in a Turkish Restaurant in Nashville--not exactly what we were planning.  Living in New York, I would never pick a restaurant in a strip mall, because, perhaps with some suburban prejudice, I assume all food in a mall or strip mall is watered down and commercial garbage.  Hopefully I've learned my lesson because Anatolia is outstanding in every way.Started with the sampler, including the best grape leaves I've ever had. I don't usually like them but these were unique, much more sophisticated flavors than I've ever had. The Hummus was light, creamy, and tangy, but the real stars were the filo dough/cheese thingies you dip in a rose petal and cherry sauce. I could have eaten many more of them, and my girlfriend and I thought of a friend of ours who would have gorged himself! For dinner I had a spinach stuffed chicken breast and got both sauce options, as suggested by our excellent waitress. The coconut sauce was forgettable but the tomato was among my favorite from any cuisine. It was bright and tangy with just enough sweetness, and the basil came through in a refreshingly subtle way. Regarding the rice pilaf, my girlfriend said, "I shoveled a fork into my mouth before I swallowed the last bite. I almost choked." Some greedy eating, which only happens with food you love.We finished the meal with a couple of Turkish coffees, and, you guessed it, the best I've ever had. As a testament to her love for me, my girl pushed her coffee my way, and said, "Finish it. You obviously enjoyed yourself."The service was excellent on all fronts. Ayla, our waitress, was attentive but not overly so, which I find is sort of the southern style. I kind of prefer to have my food put down, maybe one follow up, then to be left alone while the server can be reached visually if anything comes up, and that was Ayla. Then Greg kindly gave me some sage suggestions on a quick survey of Nashville. I'd definitely come back and pledge to keep an open mind around strip mall cuisine.

reviews.name: Ed K.
reviews.review: Updated from Oct 2012,....I've been a regular since it opened a decade ago.  The reason Anatolia thrives is because they make fresh, healthy food & serve it in a pleasant environment by excellent servers.  I love the roasted lamb...just had it tonight for the umpteenth time.  Don't forget the Kunufe.

reviews.name: Anne D.
reviews.review: Huge fan of this place!  It's not the sort you would drive by and think, "Wow, I have to try that Turkish restaurant in the strip mall."  However, if you do, you'll be pleasantly surprised.The atmosphere is much better on the inside than the exterior.  It's not the swankiest restaurant around, but it's definitely passable.The food is outstanding.  This is a great place to come for dinner, and recount the day's events over food that is reasonably healthy, with a glass of red wine.  There are a number of great vegetarian dishes on the menu which I usually gravitate towards--even though I am not actually vegetarian.  Hummus is delicious, but the haydari is something I can't live without.  My husband and I usually order an appetizer with half of each, and it's gone in 60 seconds.  There's a ravioli dish on the menu, and every time I order it, the server cautions me that patrons either love it or hate it.  I always smile and say I know...but you can safely place me in the ravioli-lover camp.  I can see why people who order it (thinking it's standard ravioli fare) would be disappointed, because it's nothing like it.  It comes in small bite-sized doses of ground lamb in pasta, with a thick tangy yogurt sauce laced with butter and mint.  But if you're in the mood for something a little more uncharted, it's a total win.  Still, you may want to try the haydari as an appetizer to test out your response to the yogurt, before committing to the entree.The ravioli is good, but my favorite dish is probably the Turkish stew (either with lamb or the vegetarian option), which comes in a Very Hot bowl.  You're probably going to want to let it cool off a bit, but the vegetables have always been cooked to perfection, every time I have ordered it--and that's at least three dozen times.  The veggie sampler is a veggie stuffed eggplant with a stuffed artichoke on the side.  This is the entree that may inspire me to write a pine-nut love rhapsody at some point.  The rice pilaf is delicious dipped in the yogurt sauce accompaniments.  And I would be remiss if I didn't mention the shrimp saute.  I've never been able to tear myself away from the other options to order it myself, but I always steal some of my husband's and it really is all that.  He also enjoys the fish specials (salmon and halibut).Hot Turkish tea is good but Turkish coffee will always have my heart.  And their baklava.  Oh, baklava...just take my advice, save room for dessert.Finally, I really love the servers.  They are just wonderful, friendly and attentive.  All around, a great restaurant!  Probably just as well (for me) that it isn't as high profile as some of the trendier spots, because I love being able to always get a table for some of the best food in Nashville!

reviews.name: Megan M.
reviews.review: Anatolia is one of my favorite places to eat and I've been there a number of times now. The staff is always super friendly and graciously answered my dining companion's questions. Anatolia is part of a strip mall, but don't let that fool you. The inside is nice enough for a Saturday date yet casual enough for a Tuesday night after work when you don't feel like cooking. It would be a killer stand alone restaurant, but it's good as is too. Anyway, here's what I recommend:Stuffed GrapeleavesHaydariHummusIskender Kabob (I order this every time)Grilled Veggies (seriously, omg)Kunefe (order ahead of time!)If I tried more items on the menu, I would probably like those too but I always seem to order the same thing over and over. Portions: I usually have enough left over for lunch the next day. Consistency: Not too bad, but my rice was a little chilly the last time I visited. The Haydari seemed slightly different than last time too, but still delicious. Wine: They serve it. But, there's a reason Turkey isn't known for their wines. They definitely have other wines too. Prices: A little pricey, so I don't make it here as often as I want to. Service: Top notch. Very accommodating. I've rarely waited for a table.Comparisons: Compared to other Turkish restaurants in TN, this one is probably my favorite, although each has their strengths. Parking: Tons of parking lot parking shared with the rest of the strip mall.

reviews.name: Keith L.
reviews.review: My chicken skewers and side of hummus was a really good $12-15 meal...unfortunately they charged $23 for it. The food is tasty, but their prices are out of whack which makes my visits there much more rare than I would prefer.

reviews.name: Blair S.
reviews.review: I enjoyed the appetizer sampler, particularly the hummus and stuffed grape leaves. The lamb chops were good and the lamb shish kabob was good.I ordered the kunefe dessert with my meal because it takes 20 minutes to prepare. The waiter repeated the order back to us but apparently not to the kitchen. Instead, shortly after taking our orders, he decided to spend all of his time waiting on his friends in the back. Well after we finished our meal he finally returned to take our plates and ask if we wanted dessert. We asked about kunefe, and got it approximately 30 minutes later.The atmosphere on a weekend evening was nice. However, I was seated near the door, which people kept holding open even when no one was behind them. I guess it wouldn't have been a problem if the service hadn't ignored us for so long.I might try it again for the food but I'll definitely make sure I sit away from the door and get a different server.

reviews.name: Jill S.
reviews.review: We loved everything we had at this place! Service was great, and the food was excellent! We definitely plan to go back soon!

reviews.name: Tonya O.
reviews.review: While Anatolia is in an area that we frequent, this was my first visit to the restaurant. What a great visit it was! I had the Veggie Sampler, which was an eggplant (stuffed with onions, pine nuts, tomatoes and parsleys), an artichoke (stuffed with pine nuts, rice and currants), a skewer of grilled vegetables and a side of rice. While the stuffed eggplant and artichoke were good, the skewer of grilled vegetables was my favorite of the three. The food overall was very flavorful. I also tried two of the hot teas on the menu: the Turkish Hot Apple Tea and the Rosehip Tea. I highly recommend trying the Rosehip tea. Both were served very hot. Finally, the best part was the dessert. Upon recommendation from a friend, we tried the Kunafeh, which is a cheese center and a whispy crispy top and bottom (similar to shredded wheat). At first I thought it would be overly sweet, but I was pleasantly surprised to find that it was just the right amount of sweet. It's good to order this dessert when you order your main course because it takes about 20 minutes to be made. The service was superb. The server must have known we were new to the restaurant, because he was patient and helpful by describing the menu items when we asked and telling me his opinions of the tea. He was super nice to us from the beginning to the end, despite the restaurant getting very busy toward the end of our meal. I'll definitely be going back and look forward to trying other items on the menu....and the Kunefeh again!

reviews.name: Mina K.
reviews.review: FANTASTIC.  We go there often and it never disappoints.  with all the new restaurants in Nashville that seem to be living the motto "People will eat anything" and charge incredible prices this is the gem of Nashville.  I mentioned to the waiter I was gluten free (which has been met with eye rolls in the past) and from there on out he took care of my meal.  All the meats are tender and delicious.

reviews.name: David O.
reviews.review: On the recommendation of a friend, we tried Anatolia. I'm not familiar with Turkish food, so I can't speak to its authenticity.  I did very much enjoy my meal however.  My discomfort from my unfamiliarity with the dishes was completely banished by the very friendly service.  Or waiter was very helpful with recommendations.The portions seemed slightly small, but that is probably because I'm a big fat American used to big fat portions.We were there on a Friday night and it got very busy after 6 PM.I highly recommend trying the Kunefe for dessert which was fantastic!Definitely plan on returning again to try some different dishes.

reviews.name: Lu X.
reviews.review: Relaxing atmosphere, welcoming staff, and great food.

reviews.name: Sarah M.
reviews.review: Delicious. The rice pilaf is some of the best I've ever tasted. I ordered the lamb kebob, fantastic. The service was also wonderful. I heard about this restaurant from someone I was seated next to on a plane a few months back, and I was very eager to try it based on his recommendation. I then recommended it to someone on a plane next to me the other day! Very excited to have learned about this great restaurant and pass on the good word.

reviews.name: John A.
reviews.review: I was very impressed by the food and service. I am a pescatarian and found many options on the menu. I opted for the sampler platter for a vegetarian appetizer. For the entree I ordered the Veggie sampler, which had stuffed veggie eggplant, (onions, pine nuts, tomatoes, and parsleys) and stuffed artichoke (pine nuts, rice, currants and grilled vegetables), and both were outstanding. I'll definitely return to this restaurant.

reviews.name: Jak I.
reviews.review: The chicken kabob was a little dry, but taste fresh. The vegetables were great. Rice was better than most. The service was top notch; our waiter was very nice and obviously enjoyed being there.I can't wait to go back.

reviews.name: Randy L.
reviews.review: Nice place.  I had the mixed grill with a lamb chop, chicken kabob, lamb kabob, and beef kofta.  The lamb chop was the best of the 4.  Lamb kabob, and beef were about a tie, and the chicken was a bit dry.  Portions were adequate.  My wife had a vegetable stew, which was okay.  The complimentary bread and oil dip were good.  Our server was very personable, maybe a tad too personable.  Her boss was looking concerned about that.

reviews.name: Dagan B.
reviews.review: i wanna give it a 4.5 for not having sweet tea lol but everything was great. the lamb chops was some of the best meat i have eaten. the lamb kabob tasted like ribeye. the chicken was good and the beef mini burgers were good. the rice pilaf was good for rice. overall it was very good much better than any hole in the wall gyro place. this is a actual nice resturant without paying through the nose. really good food.

reviews.name: Kurt R.
reviews.review: This is a 4.5 star place. My wife and I went here for our first time!  We let our server guide us through what to get.  We had the sampler and the mixed grill.  Some totally new flavors We've never tasted before.  Great chicken, beef, lamb.  Great apple tea! Overall if this what Turkish food is all about We are sold!  We will be back!

reviews.name: Jeremy E.
reviews.review: I am torn on the rating here. I decided to round up and give it 4 stars, but 3.5 is what I would give if I could. The food is authentic and very good. I had the Kofte Kebab which is basically seasoned burger patties with rice pilaf and a veggie skewer. My wife had the chicken stew. I thought that was the best thing we tasted all night. Properly seasoned, correct texture of the veggies and chicken, all around winner!We also got the appetizer platter to try a variety of what they offer. Stuffed grape leaves were good. Hummus was above average, but nothing that blew your socks off. The fried filo dough with rose petal jam was sneaky good. My complaint is that I felt like it was overpriced. Maybe it's inflation, maybe it's just poorly priced. But the food bill alone was $43, and many of their offerings are served in a similar Mediterranean way at many restaurants in town for about 25% less. I don't think I should have paid more than $30 for what we got. Nevertheless, when I get a craving for Kofte again, I will be back!

reviews.name: Tracy B.
reviews.review: Anatolia was a delightful find! I've been searching for a great Turkish restaurant since vacationing in Turkey last year and Anatolia certainly didn't dissapoint. Rarely have I been to an ethnic restaurant in the US that even comes close to competing with anything I've had in the actual country, but I can honestly say that Anatolia brought me back to Turkey with each bite.I had the kofte which were great. A little larger than those that I encountered in Turkey but very, very good. The bread is great and the rice is also really good. My husband had the gyro platter and he raved about it as well. We split a nice bottle of white Turkish wine that paired nicely with our food. Yes, the decor could be better but if the food is good I could care less. Most of the restaurants I've visited while in Turkey weren't decorated much better! It did have a nice, homey ambience and it was easy to forget that you were actually eating at a restaurant in the middle of a nondescript strip mall. Overall I give Anatolia 5 stars and I can't wait to go back to try the manti and some dessert.

reviews.name: Karen P.
reviews.review: Where do I start?  A beautiful white table clothed restaurant, the staff is attentive and so polite and they make you feel so welcome.  To start we got the filo dough appetizer which was flaky and light.  Then the bread came, and I wished we hadn't eaten the appetizer because this is the most wonderful bread, soft and light on the inside with just the lightest crisp crust, nice a warm served with olive oil with spices for dipping.  I had the chicken stew and my fiance had the lamb stew.  Both were wonderful, filling and so tasty.  The rice pilaf which accompanies all the meals is fluffy with a nice nutty flavor. We wanted the Kunafe for desert, but forgot that you have to order it at least 20 minutes prior to wanting it as it is made to order....alas, that gives me a very valid excuse to go back.  To drink I had their Turkish hot apple tea which is highly addictive....the fiance had a Turkish Pilsner which he exclaimed to be excellent also.We will be back.

reviews.name: Chris K.
reviews.review: We celebrated Mother's Day brunch here and had wonderful service and food. Would highly recommend that Nashvillians try this hidden gem. Turkish sausage is great, and the Quince dessert is delightful and includes cinnamon, pistachio and homemade whipped cream. Our server was very kind and attentive, and the ambience of the restaurant inspires you to learn more about Turkey and want to visit.

reviews.name: Jason S.
reviews.review: I really enjoy this place.We have come here frequently for dinner before or after Friday night services, as it is in close proximity to our synagogue.  The staff is very friendly and super about explaining about the dishes or recommending wine by the bottle or glass.  They have a wine list which includes several Turkish wines, most places don't boast that.  If you are cold, be sure and try the apple tea, one of my wife's favorites.  She is a vegetarian, and she has always found plenty of options.  I highly recommend the sampler platter, it is all veg and cheese, they have these fried cheese rolls wrapped in filo that you dip in rose jelly - my goodness it's good!  I am a big fan of their lamb, beef and chicken; they have great kebabs, too - perfect amount of seasoning.  Additionally, if you like some of the things they serve, they have a small store right there in the restaurant, just ask your server if you want to stock your larder with Turkish delicacies.  It can be pricey, but if you look in the Clipper or any similar publication, you can easily find coupons for this joint and they take them without hesitation.

reviews.name: Matt E.
reviews.review: Anatolia is a great little fine in Nashville.  I've been here twice now and haven't had something I didn't like yet.  The sampler plate is a good start to try the stuffed grapes leaves, fillo dough rolls, and the humus.  The fillo rolls with rosepetal jam is almost like a dessert.  For entrees, I've tried the lamb kabobs and the Anatolia roasted lamb plate.  Both were good but the roasted lamb was the best.  For desert, you have to try the Kunefe just make sure you tell your waiter upfront so they can prepare it.  It is so rich, my wife and I could only finish half of it.  It was just outstanding.  Dont' forget to order some hot apple tea as well.  It's so good, it's like Martinellis apple juice that's been heated.The food is good, the service has always been on par and I haven't had to to wait to be seated once so I highly recommend.

reviews.name: Lena F.
reviews.review: Anatolia certainly lived up to the high reviews on Yelp. Our server positively doted on us and couldn't have been any better. The food was delicious. Sampler Platter...check! Mixed Grill Plate...double check! Kunefe and Turkish coffee...bliss!!! We will be back!

reviews.name: M. J. D.
reviews.review: The Saturday following Thanksgiving.  Since I was away from home for the holiday, I didn't have any turkey leftovers.  So I asked myself: "where does one go for leftover turkey?"  I answered myself: "Why, Turkey, of course." Since a flight to Turkey was out of my lunch budget, I opted for the Anatolia Turkish Restaurant, on Nashville's west side.  After driving over the hills and through the woods (well, I assume woods once stood in the area, now it's mostly Interstate) I began my Turkey hunt.  It was truly a hunt, since this restaurant is back from the road, hidden behind Calhoun's Pub.  My GPS also indicated that they were on the left hand (south) side of the road, and they were not.  That's what I get for putting my GPS on the British voice setting.  Always doing things on the wrong side of the road.The restaurant itself looks like it could of been selling clothes a week earlier.  The walls have the grooves to hang shelves or slanted racks.  Some of the shelving even held wine bottles, which was a nice touch for a place with no concept of ambiance.I seldom pass on a shot at a decent bottle of wine, and their wine list was an actual list, which is a good sign.  But the menu also had 2 hot teas available.  Noting that tea is a Turkish custom, and the hot apple tea would fill my 'thanksgiving leftover apple pie' need, I opted for the hot beverage.If you like hot cider, you'll like the hot apple tea.  Not very tea like, but quite delicious.  They serve it in a funny little glass, and keep it refilled.  I had like 3 or 4 glasses of the stuff.  It was good.The bread came out.  Now to get a review on the bread, well, it must be really good, or suck awfully bad.  This is the former.  Hot, toasty yet thick enough to still be bread, and tasty - with or without the flavored olive oil for dipping.The appetizers (5 stuffed grape leaves), were also quite flavorful.  They were cold, and that surprised the both of us.  I'm not sure if that's normal, but it tasted like it was right.  Like a salad in the shape of a egg roll.The Lamb came with a fair amount of spice.  Not hot spice, but a powerful spice that may wreak havoc if you have heartburn issues.  Not familiar enough with Turkish spices I couldn't tell what they were, but it pleased my palate.When they brought the lunch, we went ahead and ordered the Kunefe (they suggest a 20 minute lead time).  Of course by the time I finished my meal (and make no mistake, I couldn't stop eating) I was sorry we ordered even more food.  My sorrow would have to get buried in a plate of wheat and thin filo dough covered cheese.  The desert was clearly meant for 4, but there were only 2 of us.  We ate the whole thing.Nothing like being stuffed on turkey, unless it's not turkey.  And it wasn't.  It was lamb. The lamb might have been from Turkey, so I guess that counts. Did you know they don't have turkeys in Turkey?  Now I have to drive to Sandwich, New Hampshire to see if they have sandwiches there.  Maybe a turkey sandwich.  I digress...As a bonus, we came here armed with a coupon from the "Entertainment" book, which saved us $10.  After taking the $10 off the bill, the waiter gave us the coupon back, to use on our next visit.  And we will use it again.

reviews.name: Carolyn C.
reviews.review: What an amazing place! The kofta and tea were just what I needed and the service was impeccable. Highly recommend.

reviews.name: Aaron D.
reviews.review: I came for lunch with a couple of friends today and ordered a gyro sandwich (reasonably priced at less than $7 with an accompanying side of fries).The waiter kindly offered alternatives to the fries, including a salad.Waiter: "Would you like everything on the salad?"Me: "What's everything?"Waiter: "Tomatoes, onions, cucumbers, etc."Me: "Oh, sure."(Well, you have to ask when someone says 'everything'. Otherwise you might inadvertently end up with sheep's tongue or something on your salad. Not that there's anything wrong with that, if you're into sheep's tongue.)Anyway, the gyro was good, the salad was small and *very* lightly dressed, but it tasted fresh. My dining companions seemed to like their food (another gyro and a shrimp kebab plate).Incidentally, when my gyro arrived, it still came with fries, so I ended up with both fries and salad, but I think that was a small oversight on the kitchen's part. Having sampled both, I would encourage you to go with the salad. The fries are fine, but unremarkable. The salad is better and healthier for you.Service and ambiance are both nice. Restroom was clean. I like the bowl of chocolate mints available on the host stand.Tip - If you're in the mood for a different sort of beverage, try the sour cherry juice.The only low note? A fly buzzed around the table for a bit before landing on our hummus appetizer. After that, I didn't try any more of the hummus, which was a shame, because it was quite tasty.Without the fly interloper, I would probably have awarded 4 stars.

reviews.name: Kenneth B.
reviews.review: This restaurant was a pleasant surprise and if you want something a little different I recommend visiting Anatolia.  My client treated me to lunch last week and bragged about the food.  The restaurant had a nice relaxed atmosphere and the staff was excellent and attentive.  We started out with some delicious hummus and pita bread along with some hot Turkish apple tea and rose hip tea.  The hot tea was terrific (no need to sweeten the tea).   I had the Spinach Stuffed Chicken that was a chicken stuffed with parsley, mushrooms, onions, spinach and mozzarella cheese.  You have a choice of coconut sauce or tomato sauce.  I selected the tomato sauce which was very mild.  My client and friend had the Sac Kavurma that was marinated baby lamb roasted with white onions, tomatoes, bell peppers.  Both dishes were served with flavored rice.I will say the food had a home cooked presentation but the taste made up for the lack of plating.  I look forward to going back for dinner at some point and see what else is on the menu.

reviews.name: Alishah N.
reviews.review: My wife and I love Anatolia. The food is great, and the portions are just the right amount without making you feel stuffed. In fact, it leaves enough room for the freshly made baklava, and a Turkish coffee. Whenever we have family or friends visit, we love to take them there. It's a real treat to have a place like this in Nashville.

reviews.name: Michael H.
reviews.review: The service was really good. I had the Hummus for an app and it was great. I had the Anatolia and it was good but not great. Overall I would recommend this restaurant.

reviews.name: Johnny C.
reviews.review: Best Turkish food I had in the us so far, unfortunately I had to drive 10 hours because I live in dc. The food remind me the time I spent in turkey during my childhood . Highly recommended .

reviews.name: Dessa T.
reviews.review: I tried Anatolia based on the yelp reviews and I am VERY glad that I did! The staff is extremely friendly, and the atmosphere is very welcoming and relaxed--sort of felt like a casual dinner party at a friend's house. The groups of diners were pretty diverse-- a large, multi-generational family, a group of dressed up elderly folks, and couples on dates. Despite what you might think, it worked to have everyone all together in one big room; in fact, I think enhanced, rather than detracted from my dining experience. As for food, we started with falafel and hummus. The falafel had a bit of a kick, which I really liked. It's hard to mess up hummus and pita bread. I had the chicken kabobs and my dining partner had the lamb kabobs. Both were excellent - the meat was cooked and seasoned perfectly. Very juicy and tasty. I think someone else said you can tell all the ingredients are fresh and I would have to agree.The dinner was flawless - I will definitely be back!

reviews.name: Jeb B.
reviews.review: Wasn't great.  Sorta bland and uninteresting.  I wouldn't go again.

reviews.name: mumin k.
reviews.review: Anatolia is the best Turkish restaurants in Nashville. How do I know? Well, I am Turkish and I have been to all Turkish restaurants. I go there quite often and find the atmosphere to be pretty good. The food is also very good. I really like the Turkish meatballs and mixed grill plate. The appetizers are also very good. The sample appetizer plate is very good. Now, if you go there you must try the Kunefe desert, they make it very good. You have to order this in advance though becuase the prep takes some time. The service has always been good and the owners are pretty good people. Overall, I would highly recommend this place. Parking is also very convenient.

reviews.name: Craig M.
reviews.review: First time here, will not be my last! Be sure to try hot apple tea. Server VERY friendly and helpful to first time guest. Lamb kabob was great!!! Wife had spinach stuffed chicken. Highly recommended.

reviews.name: Melissa W.
reviews.review: This was my 1st experience and I will be back. Although I have had gyros, and Turkish style food before never the complete experience. Corey the waiter ensured my mother and I experienced the entire process. The lamb was like butter and the rice was impeccable. Mouth watering experience that will take me back for more. You can tell it is a neighborhood restaurant, because many people knew the entire staff and other patrons.

reviews.name: Lisa C.
reviews.review: Yum! Pleasantly surprised. Great fresh food, awesome service & not overly pricy. Will be back.

reviews.name: David S.
reviews.review: I first went to Anatolia with a group from work. I had never been even though I don't live very far away. I mainly followed my coworkers'  suggestions on what to get, and I was not disappointed. I've since taken friends and relatives to this unassuming place in the Lion's Head strip mall off of White Bridge Rd., and they have loved it as well.Definitely start with the sampler appetizer platter. Depending on how many people you are dining with, you may be full after polishing off this huge plate which includes delicious dolmas, some fried phyllo dough stuffed with feta, and really fresh hummus with a nice tang of fresh lemon. It's definitely worth it, though. You can always take your entree home in a doggie bag. I wasn't very familiar with Turkish food and still wouldn't claim to be an expert, but the Iskender Kabobs are awesome. They have a great tomato sauce and are definitely worth a try. I've also had a couple of chicken dishes -- the chicken stew and spinach stuffed chicken -- which were worth it as well.I wouldn't be intimated by this place if you've never had Turkish food or aren't sure what kind of food you might get. My vegetarian friend was also very happy here. Definitely check it out.

reviews.name: Reg Z.
reviews.review: Best Turkish in Nashville. Get the grilled plate and some hummus

reviews.name: Claire B.
reviews.review: I've never had anything but great service and great food at Anatolia. It's one of the few places in town you can get really great lamb chops. My favorite thing to order is the lamb and mint ravioli, which the waiter told me they don't sell to much of because people think it's weird. The stuffed eggplant is delicious and the grilled plates are much better than you'll find other Mediterranean restaurants around town.The nice thing about eating here is that you feel like you're eating in a real restaurant, whereas most places serving similar food are paper plates affairs. It's nice to eat this food as it was intended, in a serene surrounding accompanied by wine.

reviews.name: Anna S.
reviews.review: When Aladdin offered to show Jasmine a shining, shimmering, splendid world on their magic carpet date, he probably included a stop at Anatolia. Anatolia is a lovely gem of a restaurant located in an unassuming strip mall next to the White Bridge Target. The interior is lovely (oriental rugs don the walls!), and the service is always gracious. You really can't go wrong with anything you order, but my favorites are the Anatolia sampler platter (particularly their filo roll, which is basically deep-fried, salty cheese in a pastry), the chicken stew (reminds me of a high-fallutin' chicken pot pie), and the iskender kabob (kabob meat topped with a savory tomato sauce). The portions are generous and the prices reasonable. Anatolia is a fixture on my list of go-to restaurants in Music City, and it doesn't look like it's going anywhere anytime soon!

reviews.name: Sharon K.
reviews.review: Very, very tasty food here.  This place is tucked back in a strip mall, so it is very unassuming, but the food is first rate.  They have some delicious vegetarian menu items, like their vegetable Guvec which is a Turkish veggie stew with too many types of veggies to list! ( eggplant, zucchini, green beans, bell peppers...).  But their specialties are their their lamb dishes and their kebabs. They really know how to grill the lamb, it was  full of flavor.   My mouth is watering just remembering this...I went to Anatolia for a birthday party with friends and got to taste a lot of the dishes,  they also let us bring in our own wine.  We had a big table of people and spent most of the evening in the restaurant.  Anatolia is small and intimate; the decor is modest but classically 'nice.'  We all felt really relaxed and had a great evening.  Oh, and the desert, it was classic Turkish Baklava and Turkish 'cup o mud' coffee, which both made a great finish to a good long meal. If you are in the mood for Turkish food, this is a great choice.

reviews.name: Puffer P.
reviews.review: Great food and service! I think this was my first time having Turkish food. We started with the Fillo Dough Roll (deep-fried fillo dough thinly rolled and stuffed with Turkish feta cheese and parsley) that you dip into a rosy jam. DELISH! We weren't too hungry because we had eaten a few hours prior, so we shared the Anatolia Eggplant. Juicy eggplant stuffed with soft lamb chunks, tomatoes. Also had a side of grilled vegetable skewers which were surprisingly quite tasty! And no attitude for only ordering one plate and sharing! :)Parking is easy as it's in a huge plaza.

reviews.name: Ashwin M.
reviews.review: The only reason I knocked a star off this fantastic Nashville gem was because of their spartan choice of vegetarian entrees. As a vegetarian, I was blown away by their appetizer choices. The Ezme and Fillo Dough roll were so good, I declared war on the restaurant and plundered their rose-petal jam pantry. (It costs 3.50$ and they sell it themselves) The onion soup was miraculous and healed my legs. I could walk for the first time in my life and all the people there clapped with joyous tears. The dessert. Oh man! How do I put this without being boorish? The Kunefe...that is what this restaurant is known around Nashville as. "Hey, man! You been to that place that serves The Kunefe?" It's something straight out of the Masonic order. I cannot describe it unless you are a fellow Mason. So please go there and try it yourself.

reviews.name: Katie C.
reviews.review: I had never had Turkish food but was in Nashville for work and a customer recommended Anatolia for lunch. I got the sampler plate because I wanted to try a bunch of different items. All time favorite was the rose jam to dip these cheese puff sticks in. The salty sweet with a hint of rosé amazed my taste buds!! Besides chips & salsa I have never fully submerged another piece of food in sauce. I wanted every inch of that cheese stick covered in rose jam and then even more! Very sad when the jam was gone. Absolutely delectable! I also ordered the apple tea which was a great end to lunch. I wish we had a Turkish food place like this in Houston! Next time I'm in town maybe I'll buy some of that jam to go!!

reviews.name: Will M.
reviews.review: The chicken isn't as good as before.  The apple tea is still as addictive.  Kabobs are good.  3.5 stars but a little pricey, so 3 stars.  No lunch specials

reviews.name: Kevin P.
reviews.review: Ohhh delicious.  My fiance and I took a trip to Nashville for Valentine's Day and found our way here.  After picking from the recommendations from some of the Yelp reviews we ended up having the lamb kabob, the tea ( it was red?), and the dessert kunefe.The tea was way too sweet for my taste.  I was expecting an herbal tea with a hint of sweet, but ended up with sweet tea with a hint of herbal.  Not so grand...  The lamb kabob was amazing delicious.  I loved every bite of it along with my fiance's turkish stew.  Her food was equally amazing.  I was only disappointed by the dessert.  Lots of people here tend to rave about the special dessert... but it was insanely sweet.  Although I must admit it was quite unique.  It's worth it to split it among four people, just there is enough to satisfy.Overall a good experience.  Classy yet casual.  The waiters were very nice and attentive :)

reviews.name: Zach G.
reviews.review: My wife and I used to eat sushi at the average place next door and thought we'd try it.  The food was really good.  Hummus was great.  Surprisingly good mediterranean food.    Haven't been back though so I guess it wasn't that great as I remember lol.

reviews.name: Hunter W.
reviews.review: I went to Anatolia with a friend that had lived in Turkey for a few years so she did the ordering. I had no clue what I would like, but I will say everything was outstanding. She also ordered something she called a "Turkish Pizza" that was one of the best things I have eaten. This was my first time eating Turkish food, but if this is authentic Turkish food than I am a fan. I highly recommend you try this place out when in the area.

reviews.name: Jim R.
reviews.review: great place, great service.little classy we felt a little under dressed in jeans but not bad.food is great hot, very good quality and spiced nice.

reviews.name: Habiba W.
reviews.review: This place is great!  The staff is friendly and the food is delicious.  I came here with my family and we ordered the appetizer sampler to start- the sigara boregi and rose petal jam were so good; i could eat them everyday!  We also ordered the lamb chops, andana kabab and roast lamb- all very good!  The very best, though was the Kunefe, we had to wait about 20 minutes but it was well worth it!  I would definitely recommend this place to others!

reviews.name: JoAnn P.
reviews.review: Very interesting place!!! Great food, knowledgable and helpful staff.

reviews.name: Chris C.
reviews.review: I visited on a Sunday for lunch and I was very pleased.  The restaurant is located in a retail center that has seen it's day, but is certainly safe. Frankly, while eating here I felt as if this restaurant would really do well on West End / Vandy area - it's hidden.The staff was helpful and "seemed" native to the cuisine. The decor tries to do it's best to overcome the exterior surroundings - but no matter - the food is really tasty.  I was greeted promptly and warmly to this early lunch with a basket of warm home made bread and olive oil mixed with spices.  The Sunday crowd had yet to arrive.I ordered the hummus as an appetizer and out came a very creamy fresh nutty rendition drizzled lightly with oil and dusted lightly with paprika.  Accompanying was hot grilled pita bread. Nice start....Waiter recommend mixed grill plate and it was very good. You can tell it wasn't cooked on a griddle or the like. The lamb kabob was perfectly medium and te chicken was cooked well - not special. There was one mini lamb chop that was good and the ground lamb patty (forgot name) was very tasty.  The dish was served with a side of white rice cooked perfectly aldente.  Also, included an uninspired veggie kabob.   It would have been nice to have a very small salad of greens on the plate.I will give this restaurant another try.... this place didn't blow me away by any means but maybe it was because I went on a Sunday for lunch.  There were only about 4 tables full.

reviews.name: Joe L.
reviews.review: Great food and super wait staff. We had a wonderful time at Anatolia's for my 50th birthday!!

reviews.name: Megan T.
reviews.review: I tend to focus my diet on mediterranean food, so I definitely appreciate this place. I wasn't a big fan of the lamb, in fact it tasted more like mutton to me but I have to admitt it has been years since I last tried either. I'm not much of a connoisseur of lamb and it could be that I just don't care for the taste any longer. The vegetable kebabs are to die for, I enjoyed those. I also had the Kunefe, but to be honest it wasn't as great as I had expected it to be.

reviews.name: Caitlin D.
reviews.review: Anatolia is nestled in a strip mall near Target on White Bridge Rd. It's interior is simple but inspired, with built in racks for wine all over the walls, which was interesting. The food was fantastic, the flavors were full but not overwhelming. We had eggplant stuff with chunks of chicken, smothered in a white, light type of cheese that I'm not even sure what it was, but it was tasty, as well as lamb kabobs with veggies. Both came with the tzaziki (sp?) sauce, which was slightly minty and realllly good. The salad that came with it wasn't too special, but the dip for the bread ws delish! Dessert was overwhelmingly large in portion size, and verrry sweet and nutty. I would definitely come back here. Recommended!

reviews.name: D.T. B.
reviews.review: This is one of the first restaurants we tried when we visited Nashville.  We moved from NYC so have pretty decent expectations for Turkish and middle eastern food.  It was one of our best experiences!  All entrees are great - hummus is great, kabobs are juicy and smokie, and HIGHLY recommend the baklava...it's the best we've ever had.  Was very crowded on the night we went, so it's best to call in for reservations ahead of time.  Nice and friendly service...despite the long wait outside, no one rushed us.

reviews.name: Kim U.
reviews.review: I've been here and gotten takeout from here too many times to count and every experience has been great. The food is high quality, seasoned perfectly, and uniformly delicious. I haven't tried anything here that I haven't loved. Their hummus is definitely my favorite in Nashville, and their Turkish Gyros are delicious. It's the little things that make this a great restaurant though - the delicious skewer of grilled veggies that come with the gyros, the grilled pita bread that comes with the hummus, the tasty and usually warm wheat bread served with olive oil & spices to start your meal. These little touches move it from just being a good restaurant to being great. In addition, if you eat in, the service is always excellent. The waitstaff are knowledgeable and efficient and are there when you need them, but don't disrupt your meal otherwise. If you really want a treat, order the kunefe (for dessert) when you order your entrees. It's big enough to split between several people, but a delicious ending to the meal. Another great dish that I hesitated to try at first: the manti, basically meat-filled small dumplings. Probably not to everyone's taste, but give it a try if you want something a little different.

reviews.name: Dusty K.
reviews.review: Anatolia may be the best restaurant I've visited in Nashville.  The food was simply outstanding.  And Turkish?  In a strip mall?  It doesn't get any more funky than this.Walking in I felt like I re-entered the 1980s.  The Mediterranean-ish theme put me back more than 20 years.  I'm surprised I wasn't given a bottle of Aqua Net and some Reebok pumps upon entry.  I guess that's my way of saying you won't be blown away by ambiance here but it's the food that really shines.  For starters they bring you some bread with a small bowl of spices to which you add as much olive oil as you please. We ordered the Haydari to start, a thick homemade yogurt with chopped walnuts, garlic, carrots and dried mint folded in and served with triangle slices of toasted pita bread.  I'm not lying when I say this was one of the best things I've ever eaten.  I could eat that everyday, it was delicious.  It was so good that once the pita bread was gone, I began dipping the other bread in and eating that.  Had we run out of bread, I may have just dipped my finger in or part of my shoe or anything else within reach.  I think you get the point.  Seriously...order this.For dinner I went with the Turkish gyros served with cucumber sauce, rice and grilled vegetables.  The vegetables were charred and had that wonderful smoke flavor to them that reminds you of summer.  My only complaint is that I wish there was less meat and more vegetables.  But if I were honest, I would say that you can do better in selecting a different entree.  It's not that I didn't like it, I just know there are better options on the menu.  And after mowing through the Haydari in record time, my expectations rose.Will I be back?  Hell yes.  That Haydari is something I may almost fly to Nashville to order.  I love this place.

reviews.name: Taylor H.
reviews.review: Great staff and turkish food.  Not terribly adventurous but tasty.

reviews.name: Kathryn E.
reviews.review: I had such a wonderful dining experience at Anatolia! The sampler platter is a MUST! The hummus had a tad too much garlic for my liking, but I double-dipped in the oil/vinegar concoction they serve with the bread to tone it down some. Stuffed grape leaves were YUMMY and feta-stuffed phillo dough dipped in rose petal jam were YUMMY YUMMY!! I ordered the chicken kabob and it was delicious! My fellow diner was kind enough to share his beef gyro and it was even better than the kabob! Who knew gyro is pronounced differently in different countries?? Great staff! The kunefe  was good...not great simply because my motto on dessert is "if it's not chocolate, it's not dessert!" My family LOVED it though!

reviews.name: Eric S.
reviews.review: Stopped in here this evening, first night in Nashville. We wanted to try something different. Expecting a crowd due to the high ratings on yelp, we called in reservations but showed up pleasantly surprised to a not packed and quiet restaurant. Lovely atmosphere and nice people. Throughout dinner people kept coming in the door and by the time we left the place was almost full, but still completely quiet enough to have easy conversation. Oh yeah, the food ; ) Was great! I don't have much to compare it too, but I would go back, the meals range all over the price scale but are all affordable. The best part of this restaurant was the service. Our waiter Greg was the best I have had all year, friendly and very willing to offer advice on Nashville. It was nice to have service with a smile. Overall a great experience and if I am ever in Nashville again I will be back!

reviews.name: Rima C.
reviews.review: After three years of living in Boston and being spoiled by the city's food, I now spend most of my time in a Nashville suburb filled with nothing but chains. I don't hate chains, mind you--I'm not that kind of arrogant yuppie. I just miss the variety.Anatolia brings me back, though. I love this place and I don't mind venturing into Nashville just to get there. The food is superb--really flavorful. I recommend this place highly.It gets major points for quality, quantity, service, and parking. :)

reviews.name: Jimmy S.
reviews.review: Authentic and delicious. Nice atmosphere, but the service is what puts it over the top. My waiter was very accommodating and kind.If you're unfamiliar with Turkish dishes, the Sampler Platter is a must. Also, the kunefe is exquisite.

reviews.name: Molly L.
reviews.review: While the restaurant is in an unassuming strip mall, it has awesome food and great service. I've been several times and the kabobs and all other food are top-notch. Also, the rose tea and turkish coffee are excellent.

reviews.name: Amrita J.
reviews.review: So I leave my hotel room venturing for a nice dinner out. I had it all planned out, I was going to go to Calhoun's (which is across the street in the same shopping center), I was going to get a BBQ pull pork sandwich/plate, and a beer and call it a day.........That was until I pulled in and saw the other options (ie- Anatolia's-Turkish Restaurant), immediately, without a second thought I couldn't stop thinking "kabobsssssssss"   YUMMMMMM!!!!!    So I had to change my dining option for the night, and boy am I glad that I did.I step foot indoors, and it's a very nice and quaint place, music is nice and adds to the "mediterranean" atmosphere. I had the chicken kabobs, which were yummy. Also, they give you bread to start with some kind of oil dip, and I enjoyed that as well, I think it was roasted red peppers or something in it. Anyways, the kabobs were nice and tender, came right off the skewer. It came with rice (which I felt was a bit dry, I wish their was something to add too it to add some flavor), but other than that it was good. Also, I wasn't really feeling the yogurt sauce as much, even though it tasted good, I wished it was a bit thicker, more like tzatziki sauce. But overall, it was a good filling dish.The waitstaff was very friendly also, which definitely helps!So the next time you stop on this side of town, don't let the somewhat "sketchy" area freak you out, drive a bit further down the road and you'll come across this place

reviews.name: Carla C.
reviews.review: Went here for dinner on a Sunday night.  We were really impressed.  The wait staff was attentive and pleasant.  The homemade bread was fresh and warm and tasted fantastic with the olive oil & spices dip.  I ordered the roasted lamb and my husband got the mixed grill plate.  The portions were generous and tasty.  The roasted lamb was particularly good and very authentic.  We were so full we didn't get dessert!

reviews.name: Matthew S.
reviews.review: Not busy on a Thursday night. Being a slow night, we had excellent service. I hear that this place can get pretty slow when crowded, but we did not have that problem at all. The Turkish Apple Tea was great and every time I finished a cup, they were right there refilling it. My friend and I had the Mixed Grill and the Veggie Sampler. It was a nice way to sample a lot of different things. I was very pleased. The kabobs are excellent. The vegetables are nicely seasoned, but a little oily from the grill. The rice pilaf was not amazing, but still quite good. The yogurt dip was very flavorful. Overall, it is a surprisingly authentic Turkish experience. The brothers who own this place wanted to give a sampling of what people would actually eat in their homes in Turkey, rather than what a Turkish restaurant would offer. While the dcor is a little sparse, I highly recommend this restaurant. p.s. Turkish is very similar to Greek and other Mediterranean cuisine. Expect yogurt sauces, garlic, mint, lamb, thinly layered pastry dough, and cheeses.  p.p.s This place has a great selection of vegetarian-friendly options.

reviews.name: Meg B.
reviews.review: Just moved from Nashville to TX, and this is one of the few restaurants that I will miss. Frankly, there just aren't many good, reasonably priced restaurants in Nashville. Many places are over-priced or mediocre, catering to the country music tourists. There are also lots of large, generic chain restaurants. This place is unique, tasty, and very reasonably priced.  Don't let the strip mall exterior fool you! (The inside is actually very comfortable.) I wanted to write a positive review as my thanks for all the delicious meals I ate there over the years. We ate here on many occasions, and we never had a bad meal or bad service. Honestly, I can't think of a negative comment. The sampler platter is a great appetizer and the Turkish pizza is yummy. When I visit Nashville in the future, this will be on my list of places to go, for sure!

reviews.name: Miyo K.
reviews.review: My husband grew up eating his grandfather's Lebanese food and sometimes gets a craving for  good Middle Eastern food.. we know we can always find it here, served in a cozy and inviting atmosphere.   What was outstanding this last visit and which inspired us to review it  was the service.. I had called ahead to ask about bringing our six year old child and they were beyond hospitable.  I think that they gave us their head of the house,  someone extraordinarily good with children.  He made what might otherwise have been a somewhat difficult dinner with a child who does not like to sit down long enough to eat  something extraordinary.  I had  their grilled wild caught salmon, served with roasted tomatoes.  It was  tender and moist and very nice, although, aside from the way the tomatoes were cooked, would not have known what made it Turkish.  The next time we go I think I will have their sampler platter- or ask what the regulars are eating.  Delightful place, great food, outstanding service.  I we lived in Nashville, I would eat there regularly, as I think a lot of fortunate Turkish people do!

reviews.name: Lee G.
reviews.review: This was amazing. The bread with olive oil and spices was delicious. The mixed grill, I ate every bite of a substantial offering. The baklava, oh my word! I will return!!!!!!

reviews.name: Terri S.
reviews.review: Don't be fooled by the fact that this restaurant is in a strip mall. While the service can be inconsistent, the food is very good. I usually get the chicken or beef shish kabob, and I have also tried the stuffed chicken and kofte kabob, and all of these entrees are excellent. I also highly recommend the baklava.One small quibble -  they tend to run out of things toward the end of the night, so go for lunch or earlier in the evening. While this isn't usually a big deal, it can be very disappointing to get to the restaurant only to find out that the entree and dessert you want are not available (this has happened to me several times).

reviews.name: Jamie P.
reviews.review: Anatolia was my first and only foray into Turkish food, and I certainly wasn't disappointed!  My husband and I passed this restaurant for months on our way to our favorite haunt, Sonobana, and finally decided to try it out.  I love Greek food, and haven't been able to find an authentic Greek restaurant that I loved, so I figured Turkish would be close enough.  I was both right and wrong.  Anatolia definitely squelched that craving of mine, but I discovered so much more in the process.  Anatolia is my new comfort food!  Whenever I'm feeling less than my best, my husband knows to pick up the chicken stew and sigara boregi on his way home.  The latter is thin fillo dough rolled with feta and parsley and served with a rose petal jam.  Technically, it is an appetizer, but I love the salty sweet roll-ups as dessert.  Anatolia is the kind of restaurant I love to eat in and love to review.  They aren't trying to gussy up Turkish flavors in any way or fuse them with something else.  They make real rustic food using the real rustic flavors of Turkey, and I wouldn't have it any other way.

reviews.name: Robert K.
reviews.review: Okay, never had Turkish food before, but really happy that I tried out this place.  Think kabobs and good lamb.  Just like many other Mediterranean influenced restaurants, Anatolia has a diverse array of food.  The Kofta Kabob is really good, it is a beef patty on a skewer that is seasoned with some really delish spices.  I was very happy that it came with a yogurt sauce, which could have possibly been taziki.  The decor is nice inside, it was well lit and not too loud, which means it is a good spot to take your parents or grandparents! Good news, they deliver!

reviews.name: steven c.
reviews.review: Ok, so this is the only Turkish restaurant I have ever been to, and I have a feeling not all of them are this good.  We had some really good service, too.  I'll be back, a lot.

reviews.name: Jerry E.
reviews.review: Wonderful food and great staff

reviews.name: Jennifer J.
reviews.review: Great food. Good service. Like everyone in Nashville our server was a singer songwriter. Very talkative, but not intrusive. Prices were spot on for what we ordered. Can't wait to go back.

reviews.name: Graham S.
reviews.review: Definitely one of my favorite restaurants in Nashville...been going there faithfully since it opened. I highly recommend the appetizer sampler (filo dough rolls....oh), the mixed grill sampler (lamb, yes) and do not ever leave without ordering the kunefe dessert - one of the most amazing tastes ever. I have pleased scores of people with this restaurant over the years. The wait staff has always been great...this is definitely one of the best.

reviews.name: Carly K.
reviews.review: We love this place. The food is excellent, the atmosphere relaxing. The hummus and grilled pita bread is wonderful, and the apple tea is so comforting. This is a great spot to relax with friends, and the staff exceeds expectations every time. Also a great place to bring kids!

reviews.name: Mariela C.
reviews.review: I went to Anatolia for a friend's birthday dinner and left really happy. Though it didn't live up exactly to the ridiculous hype that my friends were incessantly jabbering about, for a random Mediterranean place on White Bridge it does a great job. I'm not a big fan of lamb, so I can't really comment on that, however, I did partake in the appetizer sampler, which was a good way to start a meal. I'm a sucker for good tzatziki especially when it's smothering a tasty piece of well-seasoned meat, and Anatolia definitely gave me the package. Their rice and tea was also quite good. A word of advice, this place is really budget friendly during lunch but for dinner the bill can rack up, so if I was you I would head their for a midday meal rather than a nighttime dinner.

reviews.name: Liza D.
reviews.review: Simply put, it's the best. Try the Ezme appetizer--you will begin to crave it! We've never had a bad thing here, and the staff is so friendly. Ali is the best waiter in Nashville! We can't wait to visit Turkey again, but until we can, Anatolia will have to do... and it's a fantastic approximation of the real thing.

reviews.name: Matt J.
reviews.review: Quiet, dim, silly decor, not upscale, but kind of cozy.  Please order the kunefe, if you like sweets.  Chicken stew was very simple and nice.  The homemade ravioli in yogurt sauce is very different and worth trying.

reviews.name: Joe C.
reviews.review: I love trying different foods especially from different countries. The restaurant is small, but the atmosphere is relaxing. The services are great and the foods are fantastic too. Their lamb and rice are to die for!  The kunefe dessert is a must too.

reviews.name: Ian K.
reviews.review: My sister found this place shortly after returning from a trip to Turkey several years ago.  Since then, my family and I have gone time and time again to sample their amazing menu.  The turkish stew is fantastic, as is the anatolia lamb.  If you've not had Turkish food before, be careful when the menu says it has yogurt - there are a couple of dishes that are swimming in (fantastic,  homemade) yogurt.  The hot teas, rose-hip and apple, are delightful and the friendly wait staff will be sure to keep your little glasses full.Parking is usually easy to find, as they share a lot with several other businesses in the strip mall.

reviews.name: crystal h.
reviews.review: Have lived within a mile of this place for about 4 years and just got around to trying it last night. The chicken kebab was decent and you get a good sized portion. Yogurt was super tasty, rice was good, too. The gin and tonic wasn't great. Highly recommend the sampler appetizer. Although I wasn't terribly impressed with my meal, the sampler appetizer was fantastic enough to make me want to go back and try something else.

reviews.name: Danny R.
reviews.review: Not only is the food great, but the service is some of the best around.My friends and I came to eat here and were offered free drinks on the house as we waited on our orders.The owner makes everything from scratch and takes joy in serving his customers.Definitely recommend this place!

reviews.name: Amy F.
reviews.review: This place is small, with a limited menu, but the lack of ambiance is made up for with the yummy food. I need to eat gluten-free, and the owner was great about making me up a sandwich with no bread. I had #6, which was roast beef, cheddar, pecans, and honey mustard. He served it with lettuce and spinach. It was very good!My husband had #1--(A chicken sandwich on a pretzel bun--can't remember what else was on it). He said the pretzel bun was fantastic!My favorite thing about this place? The sign that says ,"Cookies $1 or best offer". Love it!

reviews.name: Zaid B.
reviews.review: Fantastic service, and an owner proud of what he's selling at a killer price.Definitely recommend the roast beef, it's cut fresh, and with generally healthy options as well as delicious.Better off coming here than the fast food chains around.

reviews.name: Adam A.
reviews.review: These reviews are stunning. Yes, the guy there is a super nice guy - but the food is awful. We dumped ours in the trash, hoping he didn't notice, but...The chicken had the consistency of thick jello, maybe cooked from frozen in the microwave. Nothing was remotely fresh or put together in any American style. Even the Parmesan cheese was terrible. Absolutely nothing edible. Even the self serve fountain sodas were bad. We went based on the reviews here - and now, a month later, it still bothers me. Great guy. Miserable food.

reviews.name: DeAnna D.
reviews.review: I hate complaining about places, but this joint is absolutely awful. I ordered a chicken sandwich with honey mustard, pineapple and almonds on a waffle bun. The bun was a freezer burnt eggo, the chicken wasn't trimmed and was steamed, the almonds were old and you could taste the turned oil on them. It was just bland and wet and gross. That was before I found the hair in the honey mustard. I say no go! I live near this establishment and nobody is ever in there!

reviews.name: Dez S.
reviews.review: Pretty good but somewhat bland food. Super nice owner and great concept. Yummy cookies.

reviews.name: Andy B.
reviews.review: I second what Justin W. Said. A guy that takes pride in what he serves, and does it for the same price as the multitude of fast food joints he's engulfed by in this area. I had the number one which is a chicken sandwich with spinach, cheese, and tatziki-ish like ranch dressing. It was really pretty good. The grill is obviously one of those an electrical kinda grills so there was still just tad bit of grease (like 3 or 4 drops) that dribbled onto my plate, but all in all I'd call this place a really good place to grab a bite to eat, ESPECIALLY CONSIDERING THE ALTERNATIVES.

reviews.name: Chris C.
reviews.review: Get off interstate 40 here at exit 196 and avail yourself of the most unique sandwich shop you'll find on the road.Daily special combo was $6 for sandwich drink and side. The side we got was a really great bean and corn mix with some kind of cream sauce that tasted great. The sandwich was a unique combo of flavors from pepperoni to parmesan to spinich. Good and healthy selection of options plus the service was very friendly and great.Why wasnt there anyone else here at lunch? I have no idea but it did mean no wait. Get off the road and get some tasty and unique food.

reviews.name: Chad L.
reviews.review: Simple Good Food. Easy stop off the highway for travelers and feels good to support a local business owner that was pleasant to chat with and genuinely seems to care that you are satisfied. I'd stop again anytime.

reviews.name: Alvin P.
reviews.review: This is a very good place with extremely good service.  First of all this is located inside a pretty large strip mall, so there is plenty of parking.  However, it's obscured from the highway due to a bank and a restaurant in the way, so it is somewhat hidden.  They also don't seem to have a website to check out the menu (which I like to do before going to a place) but this one was worth the blind plunge. The food here is pretty much what you expect from a sandwich shop, I ended up getting the ham and cheese, with roasted potatoes on the side.  I've only been here once (I just saw it today), so that has been the only thing I've tried from here.  It was tasty, on a bun with ample amounts of cheese and sauce.  The potatoes were tasty as well, and would definitely order them again.  It looks like a family owned business so it doesn't have the glitz and glamor of big food chains, but the food is good and the prices are definitely good.  Furthermore, I think the service is impeccable.  Probably one of the best services I've seen from a fast food shop, as the person (who I believe was the owner) was very helpful, courteous, and friendly.   They weren't very busy, which I believe is mainly due to the location being somewhat hidden from the highway, but I think this is a very good place to check out.  I would recommend this place to everyone, for the food, the price, and definitely the friendliness.

reviews.name: Justin W.
reviews.review: This is an update from my previous review, in which I gave 3rd Coast four stars. This place deserves a better rating than that. I've probably been here seven or eight times at this point, and each time has been a good experience. It's a small, family-owned and operated place. The interior isn't very impressive, but then again I've never been impressed by a sandwich shop's interior. Each time I've gone, the owner has been the only one working (well, sometimes his daughter is there helping), and he's a really nice guy who makes great food and takes pride in what he does.As other reviewers pointed out, it's important to consider the alternatives in this area. 3rd Coast, for the price, puts these places to shame. Sure, it's not as quick or convenient as those places, but the quality of the food and the service blow the competition out of the water.  I'd much rather support this kind of place instead of yet another crappy chain. With only one person working, there can be a bit of a wait sometimes. Again, if you want truly fast food, this is not the place for you. If you don't mind a little extra wait for a better product, you won't be disappointed. If you have to wait a little longer than usual, Frank will gladly give you a free drink or maybe even a cookie. He's a great guy. I came in once when my wife was sick and mentioned it to Frank, and he quickly put together a "get well soon" container of cookies for her. No charge.The sandwiches are great, and so are the prices. Some sandwiches, however, are better than others. I'm partial to the roast beef on the pretzel roll. I love the mac and cheese. You really can't go wrong here. The meat is fresh and cut thick. The ingredient combinations are tasty and creative. I have enjoyed everything I have ordered. The menu changes often, and I always look forward to trying the new creations.

reviews.name: D. H.
reviews.review: Five star service--the gentleman that owns and operates this restaurant is above and beyond nice and takes pride and care in what he does. I had the chicken spinach sandwich, a side of mac and cheese, and he gave me free cookies his wife baked as I was leaving.

reviews.name: William Z.
reviews.review: Amazing sandwiches at amazing prices. If you haven't eaten here then you are missing out on a great place. The owner couldn't be nicer and the food couldn't be better.

reviews.name: Steve S.
reviews.review: The sandwiches and sides are good, and the prices are low.  I had the #9 turkey sandwich with corn and black beans as a side.  A good amount of food for the price.I came in when it was slow and the owner was friendly and accomodating.  I'm from Indiana, but if I were out this way I'd stop off for lunch.

reviews.name: ZiShu G.
reviews.review: This is my first review.I specifically chose to write about this place to give it the attention it deserves.I went there with a friend who can be a picky eater.I am easy to please, so I'm going to review this as non-biased as possible.First off, the owner is extremely nice. That is a plus.The menu is small. It has up to 15+ items but hey that can be good sometimes.As others say, this looks like any build your own sandwhich place at first.The price on everything is low/cheap which is under $7 (including taxes) Everything is fresh made which is another plus.You can chose to make a sandwhich however you like or just chose one from the menu.I got the broiled Shrimp sandwhich.I was surprized to see how perfectly cooked the shrimp looked. The taste is another story. It left a yummy taste in my mouth that I could remember. Just for that alone, I would come back for.In addition the that, the owner gave me and my friend a side cup of beans/corn with cream for free!He wanted us to eat the food first while it was still hot and fresh before we paid.Sure it took like almost 10 mins to make the both of our sandwhiches but it was extremely worth it.I'd like it if he added Fish. The menu says it could be changed from time to time.You have choices of Chicken, Roast beef, Turkey, or Shrimp sandwhiches.I want to try the alternative Mac and Cheese platter.Everything is homemade and fresh.I can tell its basically healthy food.At first look of the sandwhich, it seems like you could easily make it at home yourself. That maybe true but it's not the food itself that makes it good, it's also the person that preps/cooks it. That's something that you won't have at home (unless you are a good cook). This means the owner is passionate about making the sandwhich which really makes it good.I rather go here than some fast food place which untrusting people who handles the food in nasty ways.If you want a quickish good food to eat, come here.Help spead the word, 3rd Coast deserves it.

reviews.name: Paul B.
reviews.review: This was a great surprise!  I just stumbled on 3rd Coast one day at lunch.Very affordable, and the daily special makes that even better.  The owner is very friendly, and you can tell he takes great pride in his business - both the food and service were impeccable.The interior will remind you of most sandwich shops, but the food and service make it a destination to seek out.

reviews.name: Michael W.
reviews.review: Great food and service. I drove past this place for months before I tried it out and I'm glad I did today.

reviews.name: Michael P.
reviews.review: Family owned, fresh foodA family owned and operated sandwich shop that will surprise you.Yes they should ditch the old school light up menu for a hip chalkboard and hang a little art but you came to eat right, so let's talk food. We ordered the chicken and spinach sandwich and the Cajun chicken sandwich. They were  made to order, juicy, flavorful and very affordable. I also had the black bean and corn salad, which was a tad bland but still good. The iced tea was good, important to us southern folks, the refills are free.They are just getting started so its cash only, but stop by and support this locally owned shop and enjoy a nice sandwich.

reviews.name: Jim M.
reviews.review: What a nice man working there. I think with some help- it could be a good place. I almost feel bad not giving him more stars to drive business, but I have to be honest. Simple sandwiches, simple foods, great service!

reviews.name: Brian N.
reviews.review: I didn't want to go with one star because that gives an "ewww" impression, but I'd say 1.5 - 2.0 is a fair evaluation. After reading the previous reviews I was excited to try out this place. I do like to support local businesses and small business owners. However, what I got was just "meh." I mean, it wasn't bad. It just was not anything I couldn't make at home in about 10 minutes (minus the roasting time of the turkey and simmering time of the black beans.) Someone at work wanted to try the place so i looked over the reviews here and just told my coworker to grab me a Cajun Chicken sandwich and some sort of healthy side.When my coworker returned I was told that she decided not to get anything but had picked up a Cajun Turkey Sandwich for me and a side of black beans and corn. Since I'm probably the least picky person on earth when it comes to food I was fine with the substitution of turkey instead of chicken.When I opened the to-go container I was honestly shocked. From the reviews I read I was expecting a juicy, tasty sandwich with scratch made condiments and a flavorful mix of black beans and corn.  However, what I got was simply boiled black beans and corn. No seasoning at all and the beans could have been canned. The sandwich was just a white sesame seed bun with two pieces of iceberg lettuce, one tomato slice, two pickles, and a green onion cut in half and laid in two sticks across the turkey meat. The only thing that came close to making this "Cajun turkey" was a splash of Louisiana hot sauce (at least that's what it seemed to be.) There was very little seasoning on the turkey as well. It seemed as though maybe it was kissed with very little salt and pepper and oven roasted. There was no mayo or mustard or condiment of ANY kind on the sandwich except for the splash of hot sauce.The turkey meat was juicy and properly roasted but that was about the only highlight of the entire meal.  Maybe it was an off day. Maybe other menu items are better. However, based of what I received today, the only reason I would go back is because the meat seemed to be from a turkey breast that was actually roasted in house which puts Split Bread ahead of Wendy's, Hardee's, Sonic, etc (the other fast food places in the area) but unfortunately the service is not fast due to no employees and very few cooking appliances and the rest of the meal was just completely forgettable.I really wanted this to be a place I could get behind and enjoy on days I don't bring lunch to work. Sadly, I will not be back.  The prices are not bad and the food does seem to be fresh but it's nothing special and could be made at home without any trouble. When I decide to order food from a restaurant, I want it to be something I don't or can't make at home.I wish the nice owner lots of luck but I feel if he plans to be successful he needs to create more memorable dishes and figure out how to get the proper equipment and staff to in order to operate a restaurant efficiently and profitably.

reviews.name: Becky R.
reviews.review: Very disappointing. Zero vegetarian options (there is Mac & Cheese with ground beef, but he was out of it, no alternatives) & the sandwich (#7) could have been made at home easily. Nothing special. The corn & beans are boiled & that's it. Maybe I missed something because there are a lot of good reviews, hopefully but I'm not going back to find out.

reviews.name: Timothy R.
reviews.review: Stopped in today, a great Family run restaurant with great prices. For the quality of food that you get he could easily charge double, I swear I haven't seen prices like these in 10-15 years. I ordered the roasted turkey sandwich combo which came with drink and a side (homemade macaroni and cheese) for $6.00. There are not many place like these in America anymore, I will definitely be going back to try the rest of the Menu.

reviews.name: Rick F.
reviews.review: Great food, prepared by a man who really cares about food quality and is a genuinely nice person as well. Both Yelp and Google maps list inaccurate locations - look for the Bed Bath & Beyond - it's in that shopping center, on the far left as you drive toward it. Give it a try!

reviews.name: Megan L.
reviews.review: This was my first time eating here and I really enjoyed it. They had good, fresh sandwiches made to order. Much better than fast food!! Friendly staff and good service in a convenient location. Looking forward to going back!!

reviews.name: Karen B.
reviews.review: Stopped by yesterday afternoon with some friends. We all fully enjoyed our time there. I got the special (turkey, pepperoni, spinach and cheese) it was very good with their homemade dressing and a side of corn&beans and roasted potatoes. The weekly special w/ one side was $5. Very reasonably priced. Their meat are not shaved cold cuts but nice carved slices, chicken you get a full chicken breast.When we were there only the owner was working.  He got our orders and 5 lunch plates made within 20 min. As more people find out how good it is they will need to get more employees on hand to keep up with the demand. While we were there they were not very busy so we enjoyed talking with the owner Frank.
